i would say classic spanning tree has the following ports state block, learn, listen and forwarding on the otherhand we have Rapid spanning tree which has not too much faster protocols when it has to deal with changes in a network. so RSTP has the following ports states discarding , learning and forwarding but discarding is the combination of the listening and blocking port sate.
rstp only has discarding, learning and then forwarding. Hence from 802.1d it has taken away blocking and listening. hence these are the two combined.

A. blocking B. listening 
STP states: disable, listen, learn, block, and forward. 
RSTP states: Discarding, Learning, and Forwarding.
The STP port states blocking and listening are merged (combined) into the RSTP discarding state. 

Answer: RSTP state combines blocking and listening STP states to allow faster convergence...
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/lan-switching/spanning-tree-protocol/24062-146.html#anc3

Here the question should be read care fully to answer this.
STP has 5 status( Disabled,Blocking,Listening,Learning,Forwarding)
RSTP has 3 (Discarding,Learning,Forwarding)
Hope now we can decide which of 3 states it has combined for fast convergence

B. learning
C. forwarding
D. discarding

The question is about which spanning-tree port states are combined in RSTP to allow for faster convergence. RSTP basically combines disabled, blocking and listening STP port states into a single port state of discarding. Therefore, the answer is A and E. Disabled is not mentioned here, but blocking and listening are.

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
Refer to the exhibit.
Select and Place:
//IMG//
Which two statements about northbound and southbound APIs are true? (Choose two.)

choices.E: Both northbound and southbound API interfaces use a Service Abstraction Layer.
choices.D: Only northbound API interfaces use a Service Abstraction Layer.
choices.F: Both northbound and southbound APIs allow program control of the network.
choices.A: Only southbound APIs allow program control of the network.
choices.B: Only northbound APIs allow program control of the network.
choices.C: Only southbound API interfaces use a Service Abstraction Layer.

discussion.content:
Correct is BC

A northbound interface is an interface that allows a particular component of a network to communicate with a higher-level component. Conversely, a southbound interface allows a particular network component to communicate with a lower-level component.
The northbound APIs on an SDN controller enable applications and orchestration systems to program the network and request services from it.

Southbound interfaces are implemented with a Service Abstraction Layer (SAL) which speak to network devices using SNMP and CLI (Command Line Interface) of the elements that make up the network. The main functions of SAL are:
+ Expose device services and capabilities to apps
+ Determine how to fulfill requested service irrespective of the underlying protocol

Note:
+ An API is a method for one application (program) to exchange data with another application.
+ Interface here refers to the “software interface”, not the physical interfaces.
The correct answer is A and D.
